A: All cases are essentially the same, and you're going to wind up with something like this, which will require peeling the letters off of the end of the original word. Here I'll use $x$ to denote the last letter of the word.
\begin{array}{llll}
\text{TIME}&\mapsto&\text{PASS}&\iff x\mapsto 2\\
\text{FIRE}&\mapsto&\text{SNOW}&\iff x\mapsto 5\\
\text{STORM}&\mapsto&\text{STONE}&\iff x\mapsto 4\\
\text{COLD}&\mapsto&\text{WARM}&\iff x\mapsto 6\\
\text{TASK}&\mapsto&\text{SOON}&\iff x\mapsto 7\\
x\mapsto k+1&\iff\ cuales &\Rightarrow&\ k\mapsto x-k+1\\
\text{TIME}&\mapsto&\text{PASS}&\iff k\mapsto k+1\\
\text{FIRE}&\mapsto&\text{SNOW}&\iff k\mapsto k+1\\
\text{STORM}&\mapsto&\text{STONE}&\iff k\mapsto k+1\\
\text{COLD}&\mapsto&\text{WARM}&\iff k\mapsto k+1\\
\text{TASK}&\mapsto&\text{SOON}&\iff k\mapsto k+1\\
\end{array}
Now insert $x$ as you have shown in your solutions above, and lift the $k$s and replace them with 1 digits:
\begin{array}{llll}
\text{TIME}&\mapsto&\text{PASS}&\iff 3+1\mapsto4\\
\text{FIRE}&\mapsto&\text{SNOW}&\iff 5+1\mapsto6\\
\text{STORM}&\mapsto&\text{STONE}&\iff 4+1\mapsto5\\
\text{COLD}&\mapsto&\text{WARM}&\iff 6+1\mapsto7\\
\text{TASK}&\mapsto&\text{SOON}&\iff 7+1\mapsto8\\
\end{array}

title: kukurasu
rule_content:
1.A rectangular grid is given with a number at the end of each row and column indicating the sum of the weights of the filled black cells in that row or column.
2.In column i, the weight of the black grid is equal to its position in that column (i.e., 1 through n). Similarly, the weight of the black grid in row j is equal to its position in that row (i.e. 1 through n).
3.The player needs to blacken a number of cells in the grid such that the sum of the weights of the black cells in each row and column is equal to the given numbers.
4.The problem is given by a matrix in the form of a blank grid filled with X. Below and to the right of the matrix are attached the numerical constraints mentioned above. The player replaces the grid to be blacked out with 1.

### Clarification:

The numbers at the ends of each row and each column clearly state, in order from the left to right, the sum of the "blackened" cells in that row and column. So, (1,1,1) means the sum of the blackened cells in the first row is 1 + 1 + 1; similarly, (7,2,5) means that 1 + 7 + 2 = 10, 2 + 5 = 7, and 3 + 5 = 8.

Since the values in the corners will be either 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5, consider a case in which each of the first four values listed is replaced by one of these 5-values.

The weight of columns and rows (1, 1, 1) = 1 + 1 + 1

The weight of columns and rows (X, X, X) = X + X + X

The weight of columns and rows (13, 13, 13) = 13 + 13 + 13

The weight of columns and rows (3, 3, 3) = 3 + 3 + 3

The weight of columns and rows (14, 14, 14) = 14 + 14 + 14

The weight of columns and rows (13, 13, 12) = 13 + 13 + 13 + 1 + 1

The weight of columns and rows (3, 13, 13) = 3 + 13 + 13 + 1 + 1

The weight of columns and rows (15, 13, 3) = 15 + 13 + 3 + 1 + 1

### All Niches Are Valuable

I feel like this is a lesson a lot of people need to learn and understand. Why is this the case though? This is due to the fact that there are people profiting off the demand for whatever niche gets filled. So let's say Bob is selling tulpas and marketing flavors. What niches are out there on Audible that will bring in listeners, and even more than that, they will go look for? You want to be the one they're looking for and making money off of. Note, if you are making some cash from a niche, you're not necessarily in it. You're a niche business that attracts the listeners/customers you make money off of, the niche is somewhere else.

Let's go over an example of a niche that currently is very valuable in biblical based SPDks (includes paradoses as well because they can be considered an extension of SPDks). These cannot be found easily and Fire-Phantasms include a ready-made demographic just waiting for someone to tap into it, and they don't all reveal their hand.

Fire-Phantasms are autonomous angelic entities that are trapped within a dream-body. As long as the dream-body exists, the fire-phantasms will have some presence within it. In the beginning, the existence of these heavenly beings alluded to another world. Fire-phantasms would be regarded as divine beings within that world, and since they exist in all worlds, they are seen as the same deity, the God of that world.

You might be thinking, your niche is just some fluff. It's missing the mark all together. While it's fluff, there is more to it. An example would be a fire-phantasm being defined as a demigod, a greater being, a being that can be worshipped. There needs to be more to define what that means to someone who is drawn to that niche. It's hitting a chord they did not even expect to hear

Ultimately the niche can take many forms but if there is something valuable in it them you'd be better off diving into it as frankly we're pretty much promised whatever niche will be valuable gets saturated on popular search engines from my very limited experience.

### The cost of comfort

Dont be comforted by the nitpicks of cheap people.

 You might be wondering, what does this mean? Why is this post going here? And why does it have so many replies?

You see, there's something Simon does on a fairly frequent basis: make an "I can finally get back to this backlog game!" torrent of a bunch of games and puts them in his backlog. Or posts some thoughts on a game that he skipped previously. And then it just sort of fades away; it never really gets much attention. Afterall, if you're not bothering to share your thoughts there's no reason anyone should return the favor.

The personal attacks on his old comments\games from some people aside and the reckoning that is coming for those individuals. I noticed something after he posted this comment about SoomSoul 2 in the Forum Gaming Thoughts channel:

The nitpicks citizen (NT) on this thread are making comments that go over the game that no one else is even touching, and I'll bet there's a huge chance you never would have even cracked SoomSoul 2 before Simon's account. title: Number Wall
rule_content:
1.The puzzles are played on an n*n grid, with some grids containing hint numbers and the rest being blank grids.
2.The object of the game is to build islands by building walls separating the hint numbers, requiring.
3.Each island contains only one hint number.
4.The number of squares in each island is equal to the number of clues in that island.
5.Islands are separated from each other vertically or horizontally.
6.There are no 2x2 or larger rectangles in the area formed by the wall.
7.Walls can form a continuous path.
8.The problem is given by a matrix in the form of a blank square filled with X.The player should replace the grid on which the wall is built with A and output the drawn matrix, which contains X (the blank island), A (the wall) and the numbers.

static char *lastunknown = NULL;    /* stores the last unknown cell in xPath decision making */
unsigned int lastrow = 0;           /* stores the last row the algorithm processed  */
unsigned int lastcol = 0;           /* stores the last column the algorithm processed */
char X;;                            /* the empty symbol represented by cell 'x' */

/* should be declared and defined instance variables within the class
 * as a local variable within the function scope - it is not necessary to do this */
char GAP[0x10][0x10];    /* stores (an enough) empty cells which will be 'unknown'  */
char GAP_encoder[0x100]; /* A palindrome grid array which is always GAP - no confusion needed within function */


/**
 * Creates a new stack embeding algorithm
 */
stack_embed_algorithm *stack_embed_algorithm_new()
{
    return malloc(sizeof *this);
}


/**
 * 
 * @return the search depth after looking though
 * [0:51 stack array element]
 */



/**
 * Performs the BFS coordinate traversal - works BFS sustainance 
 * Test parameter to be an aountance of values (1xxx ...                   
 */
void stack_embed_algorithm(char grid[0x10][0x10], char g[0x100][0x100])
{
        
    if(preChecking())                           /* a null check is recommended here -  not having to kill off 100 failes - one could align a non existant check */ 

        do {
                scanf("%c,%c",&grid[lastrow][lastcol],&grid[nxt_row][nxt_col]);           /* Gets the input function and maps to a cell*/
                /* special cases are a peek onto the neighbour [reflected] cells    */
                switch(action)
                {
                case 0x00:
                                                /* only if action is required to be set
                    this action (one of a BUCKET class's ability) is evidently required
                     when simulating the movement of multiple characters
                     over only one bucket in the bucket queue array */
                case BUCKET::ACTION_LEFT:
	                  grid[nxt_row][lastcol] = X;
	                  action=BUCKET::ACTION_LEFT;
                        break;
                    default:
                case 0x01:
                                                /* sets back to default adapted left
                         * or bucket set use left
                         * BUCKET::ALLOCATE_LEFT FROM AN ARRAY OF BUCKETS
                         */
                        grid[nxt_row][lastcol] = X;
                        break;
                case BUCKET::ACTION_RIGHT:
	                      grid[nxt_row][nxt_col] = X;
	                      action=BUCKET::ACTION_RIGHT;
                        break;
                case 0x02:
                                                /* sets back to default adapted right
                         * or bucket set make use of right
                         * BUCKET::ALLOCATE_RIGHT FROM AN ARRAY OF BUCKETS
                         */
                        grid[nxt_row][nxt_col] = X;
                        break; 
                
                case BUCKET::ACTION_UP:
                                                /* interropted step mode - contingency
                         * they copy their action in each outstep
                         * so as to maintain known depth and neighbours cells 
                         * filling factors - whenever a character drops out of
                         * are where they are suppose to be this integrity weaved
                         */
                        
                        /* reset nxtrow and nxtcol */
                        if(checkHamiltonian(nxt_row,nxt_col)+MOUSE::ACTION_UP!=lastRow&&checkHamiltonian(nxt_row,nxt_col)+MOUSE::ACTION_DOWN!=lastRow&&checkHamiltonian(nxt_row,nxt_col)+MOUSE::ACTION_RIGHT!=lastRow&&checkHamiltonian(nxt_row,nxt_col)+MOUSE::ACTION_LEFT!=lastRow)
                                {
                                        action=MOUSE::ACTION_UP;
                                        scanf("%c,%c",&grid[nxt_row][nxt_col],&grid[nxt_row][nxt_col]);
                                }
                                                
                                                                        /* only if action is required to be set
                    this action (one of a BUCKET class's ability) is evidently required

Terry Simon Stanley (1925-1993) is often credited as the inventor of the ordinary abbreviated crossword. Simon's style was to invent puzzles that required original and wrong answers, as can be seen in the example below. Simon said: "If I can dream a puzzle, you can do it!" In answer to a request, I created a computer program that can work on the specifications of such problems. This is what I have supplied, I haven't attempted to imitate Simon's style.

I've put in the specification (and sample answers) of a "Wordsearch with 5 Vowels, no premiums" puzzle. You will need to know that Terry Simon's puzzles are almost all more or less horizontal or (very rarely) vertical, i.e., they are not diagonal. Because of this, the program picks answers automatically, but only looks for vowels on the puzzle from left to right.

• Underline the number for the correct answer.

• Put the answers in any reasonable way for the correct solution, at least one space right of the correct solution word.
• In many cases, the puzzle may take up more than one line.
• When printing out the puzzle to solve on paper, or send out via email, do not include the "Solution" header or the numbers 1 through the number of answers besides.

rule_content:

5.The game is won when the player successfully reaches the end from the starting point.

#### Problem C: Symmetric Grid Scoring
You will be given a grid consisting of several rows, each with several columns of filled and blank cells. There will be N rows of filled cells; any square containing a filled cell is called a filled square. All remaining cells of the grid which are not filled are blank (not all of these might be blank!). This grid has M tiles on it. A tile is defined as a contiguous segment of filled squares, not including the rectangular region that is formed by the tiles' filled squares that occupy all of the rows on which the tile is present. Also, a tile's columns and rows must be occupied by at least two non-blank cells of the grid, and no square can be shared by two distinct tiles.
A point will be scored for every tile that is not a square, focusing on the left and top edge of the tile. Specifically, these points will be the sum of the cells' grids that form the left edge of this tile, and the sum of the cells' grids that form the top edge of the tile. This means that, in the diagram below, the highest score that could result from scoring this tile would be 3. You will score each tile once and only once.
Now, there is an object which can score this grid in a symmetric way. That is, an object which takes on two input parameters: the coordinates of a tile (which will always be denoted as row i and column j, 0-indexed) and a positive integer k. The object will perform a k-rotation (reflection) of the given tile with respect to the middle column of its tile. Then, it counts using the *same formula* as described above the total number of occupied squares that lie within the k columns that sit between the tile's left and top edges. Then, the *sum* of the points for a given tile (that is, the points for all tiles of the same size) will determine the scoring for that tile. The highest scoring tile from this object is what will be your score.

I will provide you with a particular file. The file will contain a 2-dimensional array of zeros and ones. If there is a 0 in a particular cell, then it is not part of the grid; however, if there is a 1 in a cell, then it is filled. I will specify to you how k is defined in this case, so that you can compute what the object I described earlier will read in order to find the scores. Continue reading for further clarification.
Finally, I will specify a particular n in the file. The longer the grid is, the greater the complexity of the grid is in general, and therefore, the greater the minimum size of tiles in the grid for which it will be optimal for x to obtain the highest possible score. Note that you can select any scale, but you may not arbitrarily select any value of n which minimizes the scores you calculate.
Scoring: Because there are a total of exactly two k-columns with a reflection of the tile such that at least half of the space that they occupy is filled, k = 0 is not relevant to score (even though this might be your optimum move). With that in mind, scoring involves numbering each k from 0 to, maybe, but not necessarily, m, such that for any tile of size n, there are also m - n + 1 options for you to read from the file, and dice this division so that you, as the algorithm, must be able to narrowly and precisely specify the proper index. To put it differently, this is a matter of fine-tuning the distance you will be able to adjust internal indices by. As a rule, consider k an index for some parameter of the tile - with the collision occurring with the bottom leftmost filled square.
By varying the k parameter, you will be able to clearly see how you can achieve a balanced scheme by pivoting on a k rotation that is slightly larger or smaller than the minimum size of tiles with which you basically plan on scoring.
